block.p: Best Bet

Just how extensively Willem de Kooning reused and recycled his own paintings and drawings is the subject of an exhibition opening Saturday at Guild Hall in East Hampton. Organized by the Fort Lauderdale Museum and previously seen in Florida and at the Menil Collection in Houston, ''Willem de Kooning: In Process'' fittingly ends its national tour in the community where he lived and worked. Supplemented by tracings and transfers, the show, with Klaus Kertess as guest curator, focuses on 22 paintings and 8 drawings created between 1968 and 1987, many of which have not been shown before.
Best Bet

Just how extensively Willem de Kooning reused and recycled his own paintings and drawings is the subject of an exhibition opening Saturday at Guild Hall in East Hampton. Organized by the Fort Lauderdale Museum and previously seen in Florida and at the Menil Collection in Houston, ''Willem de Kooning: In Process'' fittingly ends its national tour in the community where he lived and worked. Supplemented by tracings and transfers, the show, with Klaus Kertess as guest curator, focuses on 22 paintings and 8 drawings created between 1968 and 1987, many of which have not been shown before.
Along with ''Kenneth Koch/Bertrand Dorny,'' an exhibition of art books created collaboratively by the poet and the French artist, the exhibition runs through Oct. 8 at the museum on Main Street.

While the public opening reception from 5 to 7 p.m. on Saturday is free, benefits connected with the show are not. Through Aug. 14, there's an Internet auction of works by such artists as Chuck Close, Jack Youngerman, Joe Zucker and de Kooning (www.guildhall.org). On Friday, a preview cocktail party takes place at 5 p.m. at Guild Hall, followed by dinner and dancing at the Springs home of de Kooning's daughter, Lisa de Kooning (tickets $500 and up; associates for dessert and dancing $100). There will also be an exhibition tour by Mr. Kertes at 1 p.m. next Sunday and a multimedia evening with music, film and discussion, with Edvard Lieber as host, at 7 p.m. on Aug. 15. (631) 324-0806.
Powwow Power

Devotees of powwows have it all this week, with one event ending today and another beginning a two-day run on Saturday. Today the Long Island Native American Task Force holds its fifth annual powwow benefit for scholarships for local American Indians. From 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. in Setauket's Elementary School on Main Street, representatives of tribes from the Americas and the Caribbean will show and demonstrate their arts and crafts and entertain, lead by the host drummer, Young Blood from the Shinnecock Reservation, and the Aztec Dancers from Mexico and Taino Dancers from Puerto Rico. The Grand Entry is at 1 p.m. (631) 654-2841.

The scene shifts to Copiague and Tanner Park next Saturday and Sunday for the 20th Annual Paumanauke Powwow and Native American Festival. There will be traditional dancers, dance competitions, native foods and crafts shows and demonstrations from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. (631) 661-7558.
Sailing Away

Turning the Phoenix, a 71-foot copy of a vessel that plied the waters of Long Island at the turn of the century, into a living laboratory, the Vanderbilt Museum, Cornell Cooperative Extension Marine Program and the Coastal Ecology Learning Program begin Saturday a monthlong series of ''Family Eco Sails'' (weekends through Aug. 17) and ''Evening Cruises'' (Fridays and Saturdays through Aug. 26). From 2 to 5 p.m. and 6 to 9 p.m., passengers will help catch, observe and release marine creatures and even help work the ship, hoisting sails, charting course and taking turns at the wheel. The Phoenix sails from the Northport Village Dock. (631) 727-3910.
Musical Benefits
Hoping for donations, four East End organizations engage in some checkbook entertaining on Saturday.

In Bridgehampton, at the Channing Daughters Winery on Scuttlehole Road, the Bridgehampton Chamber Music Festival offers ''A Taste of Summer,'' with works by Bolling and Piazzolla and wine-tasting at 6:30 p.m. Tickets are $100. (631) 537-6368. Moving to East Hampton, at Guild Hall's John Drew Theater, Michael Feinstein's concert at 7:30 p.m. will be followed by dinner at Ron Delsener's estate at $500 a ticket, (631) 324-0806, while the Harbor for Girls and Boys on Springy Banks Road offers a more modest ''Evening of Jazz and Dance'' from 7 to 10 p.m. with the Heath Brothers and Paul Jeffrey's Jazz Orchestra (reserved seats $100; others $50). (631) 329-5480.

Finally, on Shelter Island, at the Perlman Music Program on Shore Drive, the youngsters, lead by Itzhak Perlman, play and sing Tchaikovsky and Vivaldi at 8 p.m. after dinner at 6:30 p.m. (tickets $250). This ends the programs' season, which this week includes a performance at 5 p.m. today at the Mostly Mozart series at Lincoln Center in Manhattan and the final free weekly ''Works in Progress'' concert at 7:30 p.m. Friday. (631) 749-0740.
Music al Fresco

Once more with feeling: the free park concert schedule offers something for almost everyone this week. On Stony Brook's Village Green, Irish tunes will be performed today by Gallowglass at 8 p.m. (631) 751-2244. The Street Corner Society sings a cappella at 8 p.m. tomorrow at Dutch Broadway Park in Elmont, (516) 489-4849, while the Long Island Swing Ensemble performs at 7:30 p.m. at Davies Green in Manhasset (516) 327-3110. Tuesday brings the North Shore Pops to Echo Park in West Hempstead, (516) 489-4849, and the No Gap Generation Jazz and Dixieland Band to Clark Botanic Garden in Albertson at 7 p.m. (516) 327-3110.

Wednesday's lineup includes ''An Evening of Barbershop Harmony'' with the Sweet Adelines and the Dream Street Quartet at 8 p.m. on the Town Green in Southold, (631) 765-3598, and Lenahan at 6:45 p.m. at Agawam Park in Southampton, (631) 287-4377. The Stardusters Big Band plays at 7:30 p.m. on Thursday on Westhampton Beach's Village Green (631) 288-0780, and Friday brings Rhythm, Reeds and Brass to the Sousa Band Shell in Port Washington at 8:15 p.m. (516) 739-2345. Saturday features the United States Marine Corps Band from Parris Island, S.C., in a ''Gold Coast Salute to Veterans'' at 4 p.m. at Ransome Beach in Bayville, (631) 821-9474, and Mary Lamont and her country western band at National Beach in Long Beach at 8 p.m. (516) 432-3890.
Three Shows in the Parks
With three entries on tap, it's a good week for folks who like their musicals performed in the parks free.

Today, the Broadhollow Players take us back to the era of pajama parties, bobby sox and pedal pushers and drive-in movies via Rydell High's class of '59 and ''Grease.'' The musical will be performed at 8 p.m. at Morgan Park in Glen Cove. (516) 759-6970. On Wednesday, the troupe repeats the play at 8 p.m. at Speno Memorial Park in East Meadow. (516) 489-4849. On Thursday, Plaza Theatrical Productions goes to Rockville Centre's Village Green with ''The World Goes Round: The Music of Kander and Ebb.'' The revue will be performed at 7:30 p.m. (516) 678-9338.
At the Libraries

Although most are closed on Sundays during the summer, local libraries continue their performing arts programs. For example, on Tuesday the Port Washington Library, using the Landmark on Main Street while its own building is being expanded, presents Andrew Kohji Taylor, violinist, and Judith Gordon, pianist, in a program of Beethoven, Brahms and Faure at 8 p.m. (516) 883-4400. The West Islip Symphony Orchestra takes it outside on the West Islip Library grounds at 8 p.m. on Wednesday. (631) 661-2087. On Thursday, the Bayport-Blue Point Library in Blue Point offers Spindrift, the folk music group, at 7:30 p.m., (631) 363-6133, while Sherry Palencia and the Southern Grace Band appear at 8 p.m. on the parking lot of the Massapequa Library in Massapequa Park, (516) 799-0770. The Merseybeat Band plays at 7 p.m. on Friday at the Hicksville Library, (516) 931-1417, and, also Friday but outside, the Sound Symphony contributes ''Legendary Romances'' at 7 p.m. on the North Shore Library grounds in Shoreham (631) 929-4488.
Free Choices

SATURDAY -- Lead by Markand Thakar, one of the candidates for music director, the Long Island Philharmonic plays ''No Place Like Home,'' an around-the-world musical journey featuring works by Bernstein, Bizet, Gould, Strauss, Tchaikovsky and Vaughn Williams at 8:30 p.m. at Heckscher Park in Huntington. (631) 271-8423. The concert will be repeated at 8 p.m. next Sunday at Eisenhower Park in East Meadow, (516) 572-0223, and on Aug. 26 at 8 p.m. at the Brookhaven Amphitheater in Farmingville, (631) 732-4011.

Playing ''Legendary Romances,'' a program of music about love and romance that includes works by Douglas Moore, the Sound Symphony performs the annual ''Douglas Moore Concert'' at 8 p.m. on the Cutchogue Village Green (631) 549-3881.
BARBARA DELATINER
